## Group Chairman's statement

- [[ Resil/i.rightence supporting sustainable growth]]

2021 was another year of extraordinary global turbulence, with recovery from COVID-19 a mixed picture across the globe. Many of our colleagues were adversely impacted in their personal or work lives. Even now, we continue to see new COVID-19 variants emerging and we have had to adapt to a constantly changing landscape.

Throughout this period, our colleagues around the world led by our Group Chief Executive Bill Winters and the Management Team - have continued to focus on protecting the interests of shareholders, while ensuring the wellbeing of colleagues and supporting our customers, clients and communit/i.rightes. The spir/i.rightt our colleagues have shown throughout, despite the often diff/i.rightcult circumstances, has been exemplary and I am extremely proud of how we have all come out of 2021.

## Our financ/i.rightal performance is improv/i.rightng

Later in this report, Bill and Andy Halford, our Group Chief Financ/i.rightal Officer, will set out more detail on our financ/i.rightal performance as we navigated the second year of the pandemic. Overall, our results show evidence of resil/i.rightence, with performance improv/i.rightng against a diff/i.rightcult backdrop.

Our underlying profit before tax at $3.9 bill/i.righton, grew 61 per cent on a constant currency basis. This was supported by low levels of impa/i.rightrment, a return to posit/i.rightve income momentum in the second half of 2021 and cost control.

We have continued to invest in the future of the Group, includ/i.rightng stepping up our innovat/i.righton and technology investment, and we now have an excit/i.rightng set of transformative business development opportunit/i.rightes and partnerships, many of which we showcased at our investor event in October.

<!-- image -->

The Group is highly liqu/i.rightd and well capital/i.rightsed with a Common Equity Tier 1 ('CET1') ratio of 14.1 per cent. The Board has recommended a final div/i.rightdend of 9 cents per share, or $277 mill/i.righton, with the full year div/i.rightdend an increase of onethird from 2020. We have also announced a share buy-back programme and will shortly start purchasing and then cancelling up to $750 mill/i.righton of ordinary shares.

The Board is committed to operating with/i.rightn the 13 to 14 per cent CET1 ratio range and we are very clear that capital not needed to fund growth will be returned to shareholders. We have returned $2.6 bill/i.righton of capital to shareholders over the last three years through a mix of div/i.rightdends and share buy-backs. This included paying out the maximum amount we were authorised to in 2020 when the emerging pandemic resulted in a suspension of distr/i.rightbutions.

## We are deliver/i.rightng against our strategic prior/i.rightties

While the pandemic brought about considerable challenges and, as a result, the turnaround is taking longer than previously antic/i.rightpated, it is clear to us that the refreshed strategic prior/i.rightties we set out at the start of 2021 are right. Our ambit/i.righton of deliver/i.rightng 10 per cent return on tangible equity remains as resolute as ever and we are working to accelerate its achievement by 2024. In Bill's report the actions we are targeting are outlined, which includes active management of the Group's capital, with a target to return in excess of $5 bill/i.righton in the next three years. Our strategy brings the dynamism of our markets to life in our business. Our focus is now on executing against the prior/i.rightties at pace, and we are making progress on each of them.

Our Network and Affluent businesses remain key competit/i.rightve different/i.rightators, both strong generators of high-quality and higher-returning 'capital-lite' income streams.

We are transforming our abil/i.rightty to onboard, serve and exceed the expectations of our Mass Retail customers, which will help to feed our higher-margin Affluent business, as well as being a sign/i.rightficant source of income.

Sustainab/i.rightlity is a moral imperat/i.rightve and an opportunity. Our Sustainable Finance capabil/i.rightties are not only making a difference where it matters the most, but also representing a growing source of income.

## We are accelerating our pathway to net zero

We have long recognised climate change as one of the greatest challenges of our time, given its widespread and proven impact on the physical environment and human health, as well as its potential to hamper economic growth. The complex trade-offs which come with climate actions mean there are no simple answers. We announced our net zero roadmap in October, following extensive engagement with shareholders, clients and NGOs. The approach was reviewed and approved by the Board and included inter/i.rightm targets to reduce financed emiss/i.rightons and mobil/i.rightse $300 bill/i.righton in green and transit/i.righton finance by 2030. Our approach emphasises the need for a just transit/i.righton to net zero: the impacts of climate change are felt most severely in our footprint, and if we do not meet climate object/i.rightves in a way that recognises the need for markets across Asia, Africa and the Middle East to grow and prosper, we will fail.

## We continue to enhance our governance and culture

While the Board has been unable to meet in a number of key markets in person this year, we have stayed engaged virtually. Members of the Board attended a number of subsid/i.rightary board and committee meetings and held virtual Board-workforce engagement sessions across our regions during the course of the year. The Board hopes to be able to once again engage colleagues in person during 2022 as part of its market vis/i.rightts.

We recently announced several changes to our Board Committee composit/i.righton, details of which can be found in the Directors' report on pages 90 to 191.

During the year, we refocused our Brand, Values and Conduct Committee to Culture and Sustainab/i.rightlity. This Committee, chaired by Jasmine Whitbread, has been actively involved in supporting the Board and the business in relation to our net zero approach. The Board was also heavily involved in the key decis/i.rightons ahead of endorsing the Group's net zero white paper, published in October ahead of COP 26.

## We are taking ambit/i.rightous Stands

The Group has built a unique footprint in the world's most dynamic markets, serving the people and businesses that are the engines of their growth. As the bank for the new economy, we will ensure we continue to shape our business to drive their success - and ours - for the future.

We have a huge opportunity to build a better future with our customers and communit/i.rightes. We believe that we can fulfil our Purpose - to drive commerce and prosperity through our unique divers/i.rightty - without people being left behind, without the planet being negatively impacted, and without creating div/i.rightsions that dim/i.rightnish our sense of community.

We're taking a set of Stands to help solve some of the world's most crit/i.rightcal problems - lift/i.rightng economic partic/i.rightpation, helping emerging markets reduce carbon emiss/i.rightons, and supporting a fairer model for globalisat/i.righton. As well as addressing societal challenges, we believe these long-term ambit/i.rightons will stretch and motivate the Group to deliver our strategy faster and better.

We've rallied together for our communit/i.rightes, reaching more than 300,000 young people through our Futuremakers programme to support education, employabil/i.rightty, and entrepreneurship across our markets during the year.

All these achievements, and more, speak to the heart and mettle of who we are. They are a testament to our valued behaviours of being Better Together, endeavouring to Do the Right Thing, and putting our best foot forward to Never Settle. These attributes, along with the resil/i.rightence and adaptabil/i.rightty of our colleagues, are crit/i.rightcal for us. We must continue to build on our culture of excellence, which is client-centric, diverse and inclus/i.rightve, to deliver on our aspirat/i.rightons to be truly high-performing.

## Our outlook is bright despite an uncertain environment

Whilst uncertaint/i.rightes persist in relation to COVID-19 and the geopolit/i.rightcal landscape, we see plenty of opportunit/i.rightes that are compelling.

Global growth is expected to continue in 2022 albeit somewhat slower after the sharp recovery we saw in 2021. Asia, our largest region, is poised to remain the fastestgrowing area in the world.

We expect policy support to scale back, as a number of central banks tighten policy to counter inflat/i.righton leading to ris/i.rightng interest rates, and fiscal programmes are eased.

We continue to see accelerated change across the global business ecosystem, from the dig/i.righttal space, to trade flows and supply chain shifts, and these are just some of the reasons why we are excited at the prospects of the Group.

The Board will continue to oversee the task of strik/i.rightng the right balance between the opportunit/i.rightes and risks that we see. I am confident that, with the actions we have outlined to continue driv/i.rightng and indeed accelerating our strategic prior/i.rightties, we will create long-term and sustainable value for our stakeholders.

Dr José Viñals Group Chairman 17 February 2022

Our performance in the second half of 2021, and into this year, gives us confidence that we are on track to achieve our strategic and financ/i.rightal object/i.rightves. We saw a return to income growth, which we believe signals the start of a sustainable recovery, and we fin/i.rightshed the year with good business momentum in Financ/i.rightal Markets, Trade and Wealth Management. Confidence in our overall asset quality and earnings trajectory allows us to return sign/i.rightficant capital to shareholders: we are announcing today a $750 mill/i.righton share buy-back, starting imm/i.rightnently, together with a 12 cents per share full-year div/i.rightdend, up a third on 2020. We are also committ/i.rightng to deliver substantial returns to investors over the next few years while managing our Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) ratio dynamically with/i.rightn our 13 to 14 per cent range.

We remain liqu/i.rightd, well capital/i.rightsed and soundly posit/i.rightoned for the year ahead.

## Confidence in our purpose and strategy

The places Standard Chartered call home are the world's most dynamic markets, setting the pace for global growth. The people and businesses we serve, connect and partner with are the engines of the new economy of trade and innovat/i.righton, and central to the transit/i.righton to a fair and sustainable future. Our Purpose is to drive commerce and prosperity through our unique divers/i.rightty. This infuses everything we do, connecting our strategy with opportunit/i.rightes to drive growth and deliver our societal ambit/i.rightons.

To help us deliver our Purpose, we have defined three 'Stands', areas where we have long-term ambit/i.rightons: Accelerating Zero, Lift/i.rightng Partic/i.rightpation and Resetting Globalisat/i.righton. Representing some of the main societal challenges of our time, these are not separate from our strategy, but integral to deliver/i.rightng and accelerating it: stretching our think/i.rightng, action and leadership.

We have managed seism/i.rightc changes over the last two years and these external challenges have helped us understand how we can accelerate our progress. Our strategy is as relevant now as it was pre-pandemic:

- · The growth of the Affluent segment in our markets has continued apace and remains one of our greatest opportunit/i.rightes. ## Changes made to the current policy since the 2019 shareholder vote

At the AGM in 2019 the directors' remuneration policy received the support of 64 per cent of shareholders. The Committee re-engaged with shareholders to seek feedback and address concerns relating to the pension allowance. Following these discuss/i.rightons, with effect from 1 January 2020 the pension allowance for the current executive directors was reduced from 20 per cent of salary to 10 per cent of salary, align/i.rightng with all UK employees. The subsequent directors' remuneration reports received support from shareholders of 97.0 per cent and 98.6 per cent of shareholders at the 2020 and 2021 AGMs respectively.

The Board and Committee conducted a detailed review of the policy in 2021 consider/i.rightng the views of stakeholders, the strategic object/i.rightves of the Group, the remuneration framework applicable to all colleagues, market benchmarking and best practice. Following careful considerat/i.righton, the Committee decided to retain a broadly unchanged policy, making some small changes in order to align with market practice, increase shareholder alignment and reinforce sustained long-term focus on our strategic goals. Mainta/i.rightning a sim/i.rightlar policy will continue to support the delivery of the Group's purpose and strategy, reinforce the achievement of shareholder value creation, and ensure continued regulatory compliance.

To recognise shareholder views and further align with market practice, the pension allowance for new directors will be based on the cash element of salary only. The Committee considered carefully whether the pension allowance for the current directors should also be based on the cash element of salary only. However, the pension reductions in 2020 had a direct impact on the variable pay opportunity (8 per cent lower for both Bill and Andy), in addit/i.righton to the reduction on fixed pay. Therefore, to avoid further reducing remuneration, for the current directors the pension is not changing and will continue to be based on the cash and share elements of salary.

The basis of calculation of variable remuneration will be re-expressed as a percentage of salary (cash and shares) only changing from a percentage of fixed pay (salary and pension). This is purely a presentational change with no impact on the value of opportunity.

The Committee Chair mainta/i.rightns regular contact with the Group's major shareholders on remuneration and informs the Committee of their views. In 2021, shareholders representing approximately 55 per cent of our share register and the main proxy advisory agencies were engaged to discuss the proposals for the new directors' remuneration policy. Considerat/i.righton was given to the views expressed and the proposed policy reflects the feedback received.

The remuneration of the Group Chairman, executive directors, senior management and all colleagues was considered in the development of the refreshed policy. Alignment with the wider workforce and with Group-wide remuneration arrangements was crit/i.rightcal in the development of the policy which is designed to reflect the Group's purpose as well as following the princ/i.rightples of our Fair Pay Charter which guides reward decis/i.rightons.

## Non-audit services

The Group's non-audit services policy ('the policy') was reviewed and approved by the Audit Committee on 28 October 2021. The policy is based on an overrid/i.rightng princ/i.rightple that, to avoid any actual or perceived conflicts of interest, the Group's auditor should only be used when either there is evidence that there is no alternative in terms of quality and there is no conflict with their duties as auditor. EY can be used where the work is required by a regulator or competent authority.

The policy clearly sets out the criter/i.righta for when the Audit Committee's prior written approval is required. The policy requires a conservative approach to be taken to the assessment of requests for EY to provide non-audit services. Subject to the overrid/i.rightng princ/i.rightple, the Audit Committee's view is that EY can be of value in a range of non-audit service activ/i.rightties and should be allowed to tender subject to the terms of the policy. The Group is required to take a conservative approach to interpret/i.rightng the potential threats to auditor independence and requires commensurately robust safeguards against them.

UK legislat/i.righton and guidance from the FRC sets out threats to audit independence includ/i.rightng self-interest, self-review, famil/i.rightarity, taking of a management role or conducting advocacy. In particular, mainta/i.rightning EY's independence from the Group requires EY to avoid taking decis/i.rightons on the Group's behalf. ## Movement in gross exposures and credit impa/i.rightrment for loans and advances, debt securit/i.rightes, undrawn commitments and financ/i.rightal guarantees (audited)

The tables overleaf set out the movement in gross exposures and credit impa/i.rightrment by stage in respect of amortised cost loans to banks and customers, undrawn commitments, financ/i.rightal guarantees and debt securit/i.rightes classif/i.righted at amortised cost and FVOCI. The tables are presented for the Group, debt securit/i.rightes and other elig/i.rightble bills.

## Methodology

The movement lines with/i.rightn the tables are an aggregation of monthly movements over the year and will therefore reflect the accumulation of multiple trades during the year. The credit impa/i.rightrment charge in the income statement comprises the amounts with/i.rightn the boxes in the table below less recoveries of amounts previously written off. Discount unwind is reported in net interest income and related to stage 3 financ/i.rightal instruments only.

The approach for determin/i.rightng the key line items in the tables is set out below.

- · Transfers - transfers between stages are deemed to occur at the beginn/i.rightng of a month based on prior month closing balances
- · Net remeasurement from stage changes - the remeasurement of credit impa/i.rightrment provis/i.rightons aris/i.rightng from a change in stage is reported with/i.rightn the stage that the assets are transferred to. For example, assets transferred into stage 2 are remeasured from a 12-month to a lifet/i.rightme expected credit loss, with the effect of remeasurement reported in stage 2. For stage 3, this represents the in/i.righttial remeasurement from specif/i.rightc provis/i.rightons recognised on ind/i.rightvidual assets transferred into stage 3 in the year
- · Net changes in exposures - new business written less repayments in the year. With/i.rightn stage 1, new business written will attract up to 12 months of expected credit loss charges. Repayments of non-amortis/i.rightng loans (primar/i.rightly with/i.rightn Corporate, Commercial and Institut/i.rightonal Banking) will have low amounts of expected credit loss provis/i.rightons attributed to them, due to the release of provis/i.rightons over the term to maturity. In stages 2 and 3, the amounts princ/i.rightpally reflect repayments although stage 2 may include new business written where clients are on non-purely precautionary early alert, are credit grade 12, or when non-investment grade debt securit/i.rightes are acquired.
- · Changes in risk parameters - for stages 1 and 2, this reflects changes in the probabil/i.rightty of default (PD), loss given default (LGD) and exposure at default (EAD) of assets during the year, which includes the impact of releasing provis/i.rightons over the term to maturity. It also includes the effect of changes in forecasts of macroeconomic variables during the year and movements in management overlays. In stage 3, this line represents addit/i.rightonal specif/i.rightc provis/i.rightons recognised on exposures held with/i.rightn stage 3
- · Interest due but not paid - change in contractual amount of interest due in stage 3 financ/i.rightal instruments but not paid, being the net of accruals, repayments and write-offs, together with the corresponding change in credit impa/i.rightrment

Changes to ECL models, which incorporates changes to model approaches and methodologies, is not reported as a separate line item as it has an impact over a number of lines and stages.

## Movements during the year

Stage 1 gross exposures increased by $42 bill/i.righton to $685 bill/i.righton when compared with 31 December 2020. There was a $9 bill/i.righton increase in Consumer, Private and Business Banking which was mainly driven by new orig/i.rightnations in mortgage and secured wealth products. Addit/i.rightonally, there was a $8 bill/i.righton increase in debt securit/i.rightes in stage 1.

Total stage 1 provis/i.rightons decreased by $54 mill/i.righton to $609 mill/i.righton, primar/i.rightly in Consumer, Private and Business Banking unsecured lending, due to an improvement in macroeconomic forecasts for Singapore and Hong Kong. Corporate, Commercial and Institut/i.rightonal Banking provis/i.rightons increased by $9 mill/i.righton primar/i.rightly due to an overlay taken for China Commercial real estate exposures of $31 mill/i.righton offset by improvement in probabil/i.rightty of default.

Stage 2 gross exposures decreased by $5 bill/i.righton to $35 bill/i.righton, primar/i.rightly driven by $6 bill/i.righton of net outflows from exposure changes and transfers to stage 1 in Corporate, Commercial and Institut/i.rightonal Banking, particularly in the Manufacturing and Commercial Real Estate sectors. Consumer, Private and Business Banking exposures decreased by $0.9 bill/i.righton, of which $0.7 bill/i.righton was from the secured portfolio (mainly mortgages in Asia), and $0.2 bill/i.righton was from unsecured portfolios. Debt securit/i.rightes increased by $1.8 bill/i.righton mainly due to the Sri Lanka sovereign downgrade.

Stage 2 provis/i.rightons decreased by $229 mill/i.righton compared to 31 December 2020, $174 mill/i.righton of which was in Corporate, Commercial and Institut/i.rightonal Banking as a result of exposure changes and transfers to stage 1, repayment of exposures, increased collateral and a net reduction of $31 mill/i.righton in judgemental management overlays (which are reported in 'Changes in risk parameters' in the table). The COVID-19 management overlay reduced by $95 mill/i.righton as early alert balances fell, this was partly offset by an overlay taken for China Commercial Real Estate exposures of $64 mill/i.righton. Consumer, Private and Business Banking provis/i.rightons decreased by $72 mill/i.righton, mainly in unsecured lending from improvement in macroeconomic forecasts, and lower delinquenc/i.rightes as condit/i.rightons normalised in a number of our markets.

The impact of changes in macroeconomic forecasts decreased provis/i.rightons by $5 mill/i.righton (2020: increase of $81 mill/i.righton), which includes a $51 mill/i.righton multiple economic scenario post model adjustment.

New ECL models implemented during the year decreased provis/i.rightons by $3 mill/i.righton.

In Corporate, Commercial and Institut/i.rightonal Banking, gross stage 3 loans decreased by $1.1 bill/i.righton compared with 31 December 2020 due to debt sales and repayments in Asia and Africa and the Middle East regions. Provis/i.rightons decreased by $0.7 bill/i.righton to $3.9 bill/i.righton also driven by repayments and write-offs. Corporate, Commercial and Institut/i.rightonal Banking cover ratio decreased by 1 per cent as a result of write-offs and new accounts with a lower coverage than exist/i.rightng stage 3 loans. Consumer, Private and Business Banking total stage 3 loans remained broadly stable at $1.6 bill/i.righton.

## COVID-19 relief measures

COVID-19 payment-related relief measures were in place across most of our markets during 2020 and 2021, particularly focused on Consumer, Private and Business Banking customers. Measures in most markets have now expired, although moratoria schemes in certain Africa and the Middle East countries have been extended to 30 June 2022.

These schemes are generally in/i.righttiated by country regulators and governments. Measures include princ/i.rightpal and/or interest moratoria and term extensions, and are generally available to elig/i.rightble borrowers (those that are current or less than 30 days past due, unless local regulators have specif/i.righted different criter/i.righta). Certain schemes may be restricted to those in industr/i.rightes sign/i.rightficantly impacted by COVID-19, such as aviat/i.righton or consumer services, but are not borrower-specif/i.rightc in nature.

Relief measures are generally mandated or supported by regulators and governments and are available to all elig/i.rightble customers who request it. However, in a number of countries, particularly in Asia and Africa and the Middle East, compulsory (regulatory approved) moratoria reliefs are applied to all elig/i.rightble loans unless a customer has specif/i.rightcally asked to opt out.

In most major Consumer, Private and Business Banking markets, the in/i.righttial period of relief provided was between 6 and 12 months. In some smaller markets, the in/i.righttial period of relief was for 3 months.

COVID-19 related tenor extensions have also been made available to Corporate, Commercial and Institut/i.rightonal Banking clients, primar/i.rightly for periods between 3 to 9 months, if they are expected to return to normal payments with/i.rightn 12 months.

## Assessment for expected credit losses

COVID-19 payment reliefs that are generally available to a market or industry as a whole and are not borrower-specif/i.rightc in nature have not, on their own, resulted in an automatic change in stage (that is, ind/i.rightvidual customers are not considered to have experienced a sign/i.rightficant increase in credit risk or an improvement in credit risk) nor have they been considered to be forborne.

A customer's stage and past due status reflects their status immed/i.rightately prior to the granting of the relief, with past due amounts assessed based on the new terms as set out in the temporary payment reliefs.

If a customer requires addit/i.rightonal support after the expiry of generally available payment reliefs, these will be considered at a borrower level, after taking into account their ind/i.rightvidual circumstances. Depending on the type of subsequent support provided, these customers may be classif/i.righted with/i.rightn stage 2 or stage 3.

Where client level government guarantees are in place, these do not affect staging but are taken into account when determin/i.rightng the level of credit impa/i.rightrment.

## Other Credit Risk mit/i.rightgation (audited)

Other forms of Credit Risk mit/i.rightgation are set out below.

## Credit default swaps

The Group has entered into credit default swaps for portfolio management purposes, referencing loan assets with a notional value of $12.1 bill/i.righton (2020: $10.5 bill/i.righton). These credit default swaps are accounted for as financ/i.rightal guarantees as per IFRS 9 as they will only reimburse the holder for an incurred loss on an underlying debt instrument. The Group continues to hold the underlying assets referenced in the credit default swaps and it continues to be exposed to related Credit Risk and Foreign Exchange Rate Risk on these assets.

## Credit linked notes

The Group has issued credit linked notes for portfolio management purposes, referencing loan assets with a notional value of $10.0 bill/i.righton (2020: $8.0 bill/i.righton). The Group continues to hold the underlying assets for which the credit linked notes provide mit/i.rightgation.

## Derivat/i.rightve financ/i.rightal instruments

The Group enters into master netting agreements, which in the event of default result in a single amount owed by or to the counterparty through netting the sum of the posit/i.rightve and negative mark-to-market values of applicable derivat/i.rightve transactions. These are set out in more detail under Derivat/i.rightve financ/i.rightal instruments Credit Risk mit/i.rightgation (page 248).

## Off-balance sheet exposures

For certain types of exposure, such as letters of credit and guarantees, the Group obtains collateral such as cash depending on internal Credit Risk assessments, as well as in the case of letters of credit holding legal title to the underlying assets should a default take place.

## Industry and Retail Products analysis of loans and advances by geographic region

This section provides an analysis of the Group's amortised cost loan portfolio, net of provis/i.rightons, by industry and region.

In the Corporate, Commercial and Institut/i.rightonal Banking segment, our largest industry exposures are to Financ/i.rightng, insurance and non-banking, Government and Manufacturing sectors, with each constitut/i.rightng at least 15 per cent of Corporate, Commercial and Institut/i.rightonal Banking loans and advances to customers.

Financ/i.rightng, insurance and non-banking industry clients are mostly investment-grade inst/i.righttutions and this lending forms part of the liqu/i.rightdity management of the Group. The Manufacturing sector group is spread across a diverse range of industr/i.rightes, includ/i.rightng automobiles and components, capital goods, pharmaceuticals, biotech and life sciences, technology hardware and equipment, chemicals, paper products and packaging, with lending spread over 3,500 clients.

Loans and advances to the Energy sector remained largely stable at $13.5 bill/i.righton or 8 per cent (2020: $13.0 bill/i.righton or 8 per cent) of total loans and advances to Corporate, Commercial and Institut/i.rightonal Banking. The Energy sector lending is spread across five sub-sectors and over 190 clients.

The Group provides loans to commercial real estate counterparties of $20 bill/i.righton, which represents 7 per cent of total customer loans and advances. In total, $8.4 bill/i.righton of this lending is to counterparties where the source of repayment is substantially derived from rental or sale of real estate and is secured by real estate collateral. The remain/i.rightng commercial real estate loans comprise working capital loans to real estate corporates, loans with non-property collateral, unsecured loans and loans to real estate entit/i.rightes of divers/i.rightfied conglomerates. The average LTV ratio of the commercial real estate portfolio has decreased to 50 per cent, compared with 51 per cent in 2020. The proportion of loans with an LTV greater than 80 per cent has decreased to 2 per cent, compared with 4 per cent in 2020. The China Commercial Real Estate portfolio is being closely monitored and a management overlay of $95 mill/i.righton has been taken to account for risks not reflected in the ECL models.

The Mortgage portfolio continues to be the largest portion of the Retail Products portfolio, at $89.4 bill/i.righton. CCPL and other unsecured lending remained largely stable at $17.8 bill/i.righton.

## Vulnerable sectors

Vulnerable sectors are those that the Group considers to be most at risk from COVID-19 and volatile energy prices, and we continue to monitor exposures to these sectors particularly carefully.

Total net on balance sheet exposure to vulnerable sectors increased by $0.5 bill/i.righton to $33 bill/i.righton compared to 31 December 2020 and the total net on and off-balance sheet exposure increased to 28 per cent (2020: 27 per cent) of the total net exposure in Corporate, Commercial and Institut/i.rightonal Banking. The increase is largely due to higher levels of undrawn commitments and financ/i.rightal guarantees, particularly in the Commercial real estate and Commodity traders sectors respectively.

Stage 2 loans decreased by $1.9 bill/i.righton of loans to vulnerable sectors, as compared to 31 December 2020. This was primar/i.rightly driven by a decrease in Commercial real estate portfolio due to transfers to stage 1.

Stage 3 loans to vulnerable sectors increased by $0.6 bill/i.righton compared to 31 December 2020, mainly due to Commercial real estate and Oil and gas sectors from new downgrades from 'High risk' accounts.

The Group has net exposure of $4.0 bill/i.righton (2020: $3.5 bill/i.righton) to China Commercial Real Estate counterparties which are primar/i.rightly booked in Hong Kong and China. $3.1 bill/i.righton of this exposure is to property developers whose cashflows have been particularly impacted by policy changes to deleverage the property sector and $2.1 bill/i.righton of these are on purely precautionary and non-purely precautionary early alert. As a result of ongoing uncertaint/i.rightes affecting this sector, the Group has taken a $95 mill/i.righton (2020: $nil) management overlay on credit impa/i.rightrment for the exposures on early alert at 31 December 2021 (see page 240). The Group is further ind/i.rightrectly exposed to China Commercial Real Estate through its associate investment in China Bohai Bank. ## Incorporation of forward-looking informat/i.righton

The evolving economic environment is a key determinant of the abil/i.rightty of a bank's clients to meet their obligat/i.rightons as they fall due. It is a fundamental princ/i.rightple of IFRS 9 that the provis/i.rightons banks hold against potential future credit risk losses should depend not just on the health of the economy today but should also take into account potential changes to the economic environment. For example, if a bank were to antic/i.rightpate a sharp slowdown in the world economy over the coming year, it should hold more provis/i.rightons today to absorb the credit losses likely to occur in the near future.

To capture the effect of changes to the economic environment, the PDs and LGDs used to calculate ECL incorporate forward-looking informat/i.righton in the form of forecasts of the values of economic variables and asset prices that are likely to have an effect on the repayment abil/i.rightty of the Group's clients.

The 'Base Forecast' of the economic variables and asset prices is based on management's view of the five-year outlook, supported by project/i.rightons from the Group's in-house research team and outputs from a third-party model that project specif/i.rightc economic variables and asset prices. The research team takes consensus views into considerat/i.righton, and senior management reviews project/i.rightons for some core country variables against consensus when forming their view of the outlook. For the period beyond five years, management util/i.rightses the in-house research view and third-party model outputs, which allow for a reversion to long-term growth rates or norms. All project/i.rightons are updated on a quarterly basis.

## Forecast of key macroeconomic variables underlying the expected credit loss calculation and the impact on nonlinear/i.rightty

In the Base Forecast - management's view of the most likely outcome - the world economy is expected to grow by just over 4 per cent in 2022, easing from an almost 6 per cent expansion in 2021. The strong growth last year was driven by vaccine rollouts and government stimulus and follows a contraction of more than 3 per cent in 2020, the worst performance since the Great Depression of 1929-31. Currently, the near-term recovery momentum is being curtailed by supply-side disrupt/i.rightons and elevated inflat/i.righton. Despite this, world GDP growth in 2022 is still expected to be above the average of 3.7 per cent for the 10 years between 2010 and 2019.

Vaccines against COVID-19 have allowed economies to reopen, but constantly evolving virus strains have resulted in interm/i.rightttent recoveries, and sectors like hospital/i.rightty and tourism remain under pressure. In general, developed markets have been much better than emerging markets in rolling out vaccines; it is therefore not surpris/i.rightng that developed markets have led the recovery so far. The improvement in vaccine access in emerging markets in recent months should help to narrow the growth gap in 2022.

The balance of risks to the 2022 growth forecast is to the downside. ## Sign/i.rightficant increase in credit risk (SICR)

## Quantitat/i.rightve criter/i.righta

SICR is assessed by comparing the risk of default at the reporting date to the risk of default at orig/i.rightnation. Whether a change in the risk of default is sign/i.rightficant or not is assessed using quantitat/i.rightve and qualitat/i.rightve criter/i.righta. These quantitat/i.rightve sign/i.rightficant deteriorat/i.righton thresholds have been separately defined for each business and where meaningful are consistently applied across business lines.

Assets are considered to have experienced SICR if they have breached both relative and absolute thresholds for the change in the average annualised lifet/i.rightme probabil/i.rightty of default over the residual term of the exposure.

The absolute measure of increase in credit risk is used to capture instances where the PDs on exposures are relatively low at in/i.righttial recognit/i.righton as these may increase by several multiples without representing a sign/i.rightficant increase in credit risk. Where PDs are relatively high at in/i.righttial recognit/i.righton, a relative measure is more appropriate in assessing whether there is a sign/i.rightficant increase in credit risk, as the PDs increase more quickly.

The SICR thresholds have been calibrated based on the following princ/i.rightples:

- · Stabil/i.rightty - The thresholds are set to achieve a stable stage 2 population at a portfolio level, trying to min/i.rightmise the number of accounts moving back and forth between stage 1 and stage 2 in a short period of time
- · Accuracy - The thresholds are set such that there is a materially higher propensity for stage 2 exposures to eventually default than is the case for stage 1 exposures
- · Dependency from backstops - The thresholds are stringent enough such that a high proportion of accounts transfer to stage 2 due to movements in forward-looking PDs rather than relying on backward-looking backstops such as arrears
- · Relationsh/i.rightp with business and product risk profiles The thresholds reflect the relative risk differences between different products, and are aligned to business processes

For Corporate, Commercial and Institut/i.rightonal Banking clients, the relative threshold is a 100 per cent increase in PD and the absolute change in PD is between 50 and 100 bps.

For Consumer and Business Banking clients, the relative threshold is a 100 per cent increase in PD and the absolute change in PD is between 100 and 350 bps depending on the product. Certain countries have a higher absolute threshold reflecting the lower default rate with/i.rightn their personal loan portfolios compared with the Group's other personal loan portfolios.

Private Banking clients are assessed qualitat/i.rightvely, based on a delinquency measure relating to collateral top-ups or sell-downs.

Debt securit/i.rightes orig/i.rightnated before 1 January 2018 with an internal credit rating mapped to an investment grade equivalent are allocated to stage 1 and all other debt securit/i.rightes to stage 2. Debt securit/i.rightes orig/i.rightnated after 1 January 2018 apply the same approach and thresholds as for Corporate, Commercial and Institut/i.rightonal Banking clients.

## Qualitat/i.rightve criter/i.righta

Qualitat/i.rightve factors that ind/i.rightcate that there has been a sign/i.rightficant increase in credit risk include processes linked to current risk management, such as placing loans on non-purely precautionary early alert.

## Governance and applicat/i.righton of expert credit judgement in respect of expected credit losses

The Group's Credit Policy and Standards framework details the requirements for continuous monitor/i.rightng to ident/i.rightfy any changes in credit quality and resultant ratings, as well as ensuring a consistent approach to monitor/i.rightng, managing and mit/i.rightgating Credit Risks. The framework aligns with the governance of ECL estimat/i.righton through the early recognit/i.righton of sign/i.rightficant deteriorat/i.rightons in ratings which drive stage 2 and 3 ECL.

The models used in determin/i.rightng expected credit losses are reviewed and approved by the Group Credit Model Assessment Committee (CMAC) which is appointed by the Model Risk Committee. CMAC has the responsib/i.rightlity to assess and approve the use of models and to review all IFRS 9 interpretat/i.rightons related to models. CMAC also provides oversight on operational matters related to model development, performance monitor/i.rightng and model validat/i.righton activ/i.rightties includ/i.rightng standards, regulatory and Group Internal Audit matters.

Prior to submiss/i.righton to CMAC for approval, the models are validated by Group Model Validat/i.righton (GMV), a function which is independent of the business and the model developers. GMV's analysis comprises review of model documentation, model design and methodology, data validat/i.righton, review of the model development and calibrat/i.righton process, out-ofsample performance testing, and assessment of compliance review against IFRS 9 rules and internal standards.

## The IFRS 9 Impairment Committee:

- · Reviews, challenges and approves base macroeconomic forecasts and the multiple macroeconomic scenarios approach that are util/i.rightsed in the forward-looking expected credit loss calculations

## Risk Appetite and profile

We recognise the following constraints which determine the risks that we are will/i.rightng to take in pursuit of our strategy and the development of a sustainable business:

- · Risk capacity is the maximum level of risk the Group can assume, given its current capabil/i.rightties and resources, before breaching constraints determined by capital and liqu/i.rightdity requirements and internal operational capabil/i.rightty (includ/i.rightng but not lim/i.rightted to technical infrastructure, risk management capabil/i.rightties, expertise), or otherwise fail/i.rightng to meet the expectations of regulators and law enforcement agencies.
- · Risk Appetite is defined by the Group and approved by the Board. It is the maximum amount and type of risk the Group is will/i.rightng to assume in pursuit of its strategy. Risk Appetite cannot exceed risk capacity.

The Board has approved a Risk Appetite Statement, which is underpinned by a set of financ/i.rightal and operational control parameters known as Risk Appetite metrics and their associated thresholds. These directly constrain the aggregate risk exposures that can be taken across the Group.

The Group Risk Appetite is reviewed at least on an annual basis to ensure that it is fit for purpose and aligned with strategy, and focus is given to emerging or new risks. The Risk Appetite Statement is supplemented by an overarching statement outlin/i.rightng the Group's Risk Appetite princ/i.rightples.

## Risk Appetite princ/i.rightples

The Group Risk Appetite is defined in accordance with risk management princ/i.rightples that inform our overall approach to risk management and our risk culture. We follow the highest ethical standards and ensure a fair outcome for our clients, as well as facil/i.righttating the effective operation of financ/i.rightal markets, while at the same time meeting expectations of regulators and law enforcement agencies. We set our Risk Appetite to enable us to grow sustainably and to avoid shocks to earnings or our general financ/i.rightal health, as well as manage our Reputational Risk in a way that does not materially undermine the confidence of our investors and all internal and external stakeholders.

## Risk Appetite Statement

## 3. Net interest income

## Accounting policy

Interest income for financ/i.rightal assets held at either fair value through other comprehensive income or amortised cost, and interest expense on all financ/i.rightal liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes held at amortised cost is recognised in profit or loss using the effective interest method.

The effective interest method is a method of calculating the amortised cost of a financ/i.rightal asset or a financ/i.rightal liab/i.rightlity and of allocating the interest income or interest expense over the relevant period. The effective interest rate is the rate that discounts estimated future cash payments or receipts through the expected life of the financ/i.rightal instrument or, when appropriate, a shorter period, to the net carrying amount of the financ/i.rightal asset or financ/i.rightal liab/i.rightlity. When calculating the effective interest rate, the Group estimates cash flows consider/i.rightng all contractual terms of the financ/i.rightal instrument (for example, prepayment options) but does not consider future credit losses. The calculation includes all fees paid or received between parties to the contract that are an integral part of the effective interest rate, transaction costs and all other premiums or discounts. Where the estimates of cash flows have been revised, the carrying amount of the financ/i.rightal asset or liab/i.rightlity is adjusted to reflect the actual and revised cash flows, discounted at the instruments orig/i.rightnal effective interest rate. The adjustment is recognised as interest income or expense in the period in which the revis/i.righton is made.

Interest income for financ/i.rightal assets that are either held at fair value through other comprehensive income or amortised cost that have become credit-impa/i.rightred subsequent to in/i.righttial recognit/i.righton (stage 3), is recognised using the orig/i.rightnal effective interest rate applied to the net carrying value. Interest income is therefore recognised on the amortised cost of the financ/i.rightal asset includ/i.rightng expected credit losses. Should the credit risk on a stage 3 financ/i.rightal asset improve such that the financ/i.rightal asset is no longer considered credit-impa/i.rightred, interest income recognit/i.righton reverts to a computation based on the gross carrying value of the financ/i.rightal asset.

The fair values of quoted financ/i.rightal assets and liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes in active markets are based on current prices. ## Valuation techniques

Refer to the fair value hierarchy explanation - Level 1, 2 and 3 (page 353)

- · Financ/i.rightal instruments held at fair value
- -Debt securit/i.rightes - asset-backed securit/i.rightes: Asset-backed securit/i.rightes are valued based on external prices obtained from consensus pric/i.rightng providers, broker quotes, recent trades, arrangers' quotes, etc. Where an observable price is available for a given security, it is classif/i.righted as Level 2. In instances where third-party prices are not available or reliable, the security is classif/i.righted as Level 3. The fair value of Level 3 securit/i.rightes is estimated using market standard cashflow models with input parameter assumptions, which include prepayment speeds, default rates, discount margins derived from comparable securit/i.rightes with sim/i.rightlar vintage, collateral type, and credit ratings
- -Debt securit/i.rightes in issue: These debt securit/i.rightes relate to structured notes issued by the Group. Where independent market data is available through pric/i.rightng vendors and broker sources, these posit/i.rightons are classif/i.righted as Level 2. Where such liqu/i.rightd external prices are not available, valuations of these debt securit/i.rightes are impl/i.righted using input parameters such as bond spreads and credit spreads, and are classif/i.righted as Level 3. These input parameters are determined with reference to the same issuer (if available) or proxies from comparable issuers or assets
- -Derivat/i.rightves: Derivat/i.rightve products are classif/i.righted as Level 2 if the valuation of the product is based upon input parameters which are observable from independent and reliable market data sources. Derivat/i.rightve products are classif/i.righted as Level 3 if there are sign/i.rightficant valuation input parameters which are unobservable in the market, such as products where the performance is linked to more than one underlying variable. Examples are foreign exchange basket options, equity options based on the performance of two or more underlying ind/i.rightces and interest rate products with quanto payouts. In most cases these unobservable correlation parameters cannot be impl/i.righted from the market, and methods such as histor/i.rightcal analysis and comparison with histor/i.rightcal levels or other benchmark data must be employed
- -Equity shares - private equity: The major/i.rightty of private equity unlisted investments are valued based on earning multiples Price-to-Earnings (P/E) or enterprise value to earnings before income tax, depreciat/i.righton and amortisat/i.righton (EV/EBITDA) ratios - of comparable listed companies. The two primary inputs for the valuation of these investments are the actual or forecast earnings of the investee companies and earning multiples for the comparable listed companies. To ensure comparabil/i.rightty between these unquoted investments and the comparable listed companies, appropriate adjustments are also applied (for example, liqu/i.rightdity and size) in the valuation. In circumstances where an investment does not have direct comparables, or where the multiples for the comparable companies cannot be sourced from reliable external sources, alternative valuation techniques (for example, discounted cashflow models), which use predominantly unobservable inputs or Level 3 inputs, may be applied. Even though earning multiples for the comparable listed companies can be sourced from third-party sources (for example, Bloomberg), and those inputs can be deemed Level 2 inputs, all unlisted investments (excluding those where observable inputs are available, for example, over-the-counter (OTC) prices) are classif/i.righted as Level 3 on the basis that the valuation methods involve judgements ranging from determin/i.rightng comparable companies to discount rates where the discounted cashflow method is applied
- -Loans and advances: These primar/i.rightly include loans in the FM Bond and Loan Syndicat/i.righton business which were not syndicated as of the balance sheet date and other financ/i.rightng transactions with/i.rightn Financ/i.rightal Markets, and loans and advances includ/i.rightng reverse repurchase agreements that do not have SPPI cashflows or are managed on a fair value basis. These loans are generally bilateral in nature and, where available, their valuation is based on observable clean sales transactions prices or market observable spreads. If observable credit spreads are not available, proxy spreads based on comparable loans with sim/i.rightlar credit grade, sector and region, are used. Where observable credit spreads and market standard proxy methods are available, these loans are classif/i.righted as Level 2. Where there are no recent transactions or comparable loans, these loans are classif/i.righted as Level 3

- · Bid-offer valuation adjustment: Generally, market parameters are marked on a mid-market basis in the revaluation systems, and a bid-offer valuation adjustment is required to quantify the expected cost of neutralis/i.rightng the business' posit/i.rightons through dealing away in the market, thereby bring/i.rightng long posit/i.rightons to bid and short posit/i.rightons to offer. The methodology to calculate the bid-offer adjustment for a derivat/i.rightve portfolio involves netting between long and short posit/i.rightons and the grouping of risk by strike and tenor based on the hedging strategy where long posit/i.rightons are marked to bid and short posit/i.rightons marked to offer in the systems
- · Credit valuation adjustment (CVA): The Group accounts for CVA against the fair value of derivat/i.rightve products. CVA is an adjustment to the fair value of the transactions to reflect the possib/i.rightlity that our counterparties may default and we may not receive the full market value of the outstanding transactions. It represents an estimate of the adjustment a market partic/i.rightpant would include when deriv/i.rightng a purchase price to acquire our exposures. CVA is calculated for each subsid/i.rightary, and with/i.rightn each entity for each counterparty to which the entity has exposure and takes account of any collateral we may hold. The Group calculates the CVA by using estimates of future posit/i.rightve exposure, market-impl/i.righted probabil/i.rightty of default (PD) and recovery rates. Where market-impl/i.righted data is not readily available, we use market-based proxies to estimate the PD. Wrongway risk occurs when the exposure to a counterparty is adversely correlated with the credit quality of that counterparty, and the Group has implemented a model to capture this impact for key wrong-way exposures. The Group also captures the uncertaint/i.rightes associated with wrong-way risk in the Group's Prudential Valuation Adjustments framework
- · Debit valuation adjustment (DVA): The Group calculates DVA adjustments on its derivat/i.rightve liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes to reflect changes in its own credit standing. The Group's DVA adjustments will increase if its credit standing worsens and conversely, decrease if its credit standing improves. For derivat/i.rightve liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes, a DVA adjustment is determined by applying the Group's probabil/i.rightty of default to the Group's negative expected exposure against the counterparty. The Group's probabil/i.rightty of default and loss expected in the event of default is derived based on bond and credit default swap (CDS) spreads associated with the Group's issuances and market standard recovery levels. The expected exposure is modelled based on the simulat/i.righton of the underlying risk factors over the expected life of the deal. - · Model valuation adjustment: Valuation models may have pric/i.rightng defic/i.rightencies or lim/i.righttations that require a valuation adjustment. These pric/i.rightng defic/i.rightencies or lim/i.righttations arise due to the choice, implementat/i.righton and calibrat/i.righton of the pric/i.rightng model
- · Funding valuation adjustment (FVA): The Group makes FVA adjustment against derivat/i.rightve products. ## Level 3 Summary and sign/i.rightficant unobservable inputs continued

The following section describes the sign/i.rightficant unobservable inputs ident/i.rightfied in the valuation technique table:

- · Comparable price/yield is a valuation methodology in which the price of a comparable instrument is used to estimate the fair value where there are no direct observable prices. Yield is the interest rate that is used to discount the future cashflows in a discounted cashflow model. Valuation using comparable instruments can be done by calculating an impl/i.righted yield (or spread over a liqu/i.rightd benchmark) from the price of a comparable instrument, then adjust/i.rightng that yield (or spread) to derive a value for the instrument. The adjustment should account for relevant differences in the financ/i.rightal instruments such as maturity and/or credit quality. Alternatively, a price-to-price basis can be assumed between the comparable instrument and the instrument being valued in order to establish the value of the instrument (for example, deriv/i.rightng a fair value for a jun/i.rightor unsecured bond from the price of a senior secured bond). An increase in price, in isolat/i.righton, would result in a favourable movement in the fair value of the asset. An increase in yield, in isolat/i.righton, would result in an unfavourable movement in the fair value of the asset
- · Correlation is the measure of how movement in one variable influences the movement in another variable. An equity correlation is the correlation between two equity instruments, while an interest rate correlation refers to the correlation between two swap rates
- · Credit spread represents the addit/i.rightonal yield that a market partic/i.rightpant would demand for taking exposure to the Credit Risk of an instrument
- · Discount rate refers to the rate of return used to convert expected cash flows into present value
- · Equity-FX correlation is the correlation between equity instrument and foreign exchange instrument
- · EV/EBITDA multiple is the ratio of Enterprise Value (EV) to Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciat/i.righton and Amortisat/i.righton (EBITDA). EV is the aggregate market capital/i.rightsation and debt minus the cash and cash equivalents. An increase in EV/EBITDA multiple will result in a favourable movement in the fair value of the unlisted firm
- · EV/Revenue multiple is the ratio of Enterprise Value (EV) to Revenue. An increase in EV/Revenue multiple will result in a favourable movement in the fair value of the unlisted firm
- · Foreign exchange curves is the term structure for forward rates and swap rates between currency pairs over a specif/i.righted period
- · Net asset value (NAV) is the value of an entity's assets after deducting any liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes
- · Interest rate curves is the term structure of interest rates and measure of future interest rates at a particular point in time
- · Liqu/i.rightdity discounts in the valuation of unlisted investments primar/i.rightly applied to the valuation of unlisted firms' investments to reflect the fact that these stocks are not actively traded. An increase in liqu/i.rightdity discount will result in unfavourable movement in the fair value of the unlisted firm
- · Price-Earnings (P/E) multiple is the ratio of the market value of the equity to the net income after tax. An increase in P/E multiple will result in a favourable movement in the fair value of the unlisted firm
- · Price-Book (P/B) multiple is the ratio of the market value of equity to the book value of equity. An increase in P/B multiple will result in a favourable movement in the fair value of the unlisted firm
- · Price-Sales (P/S) multiple is the ratio of the market value of equity to sales. An increase in P/S multiple will result in a favourable movement in the fair value of the unlisted firm
- · Recovery rates are the expectation of the rate of return resulting from the liqu/i.rightdation of a particular loan. As the probabil/i.rightty of default increases for a given instrument, the valuation of that instrument will increas/i.rightngly reflect its expected recovery level assuming default. An increase in the recovery rate, in isolat/i.righton, would result in a favourable movement in the fair value of the loan
- · Repo curve is the term structure of repo rates on repos and reverse repos at a particular point in time
- · Volatil/i.rightty represents an estimate of how much a particular instrument, parameter or index will change in value over time. Generally, the higher the volatil/i.rightty, the more expensive the option will be

## Accounting policy

Derivat/i.rightves are financ/i.rightal instruments that derive their value in response to changes in interest rates, financ/i.rightal instrument prices, commodity prices, foreign exchange rates, Credit Risk and ind/i.rightces. Derivat/i.rightves are categorised as trading unless they are designated as hedging instruments.

Derivat/i.rightves are in/i.righttially recognised and subsequently measured at fair value, with revaluation gains recognised in profit or loss (except where cashflow or net investment hedging has been achieved, in which case the effective portion of changes in fair value is recognised with/i.rightn other comprehensive income).

Fair values may be obtained from quoted market prices in active markets, recent market transactions, and valuation techniques, includ/i.rightng discounted cashflow models and option pric/i.rightng models, as appropriate. Where the in/i.righttially recognised fair value of a derivat/i.rightve contract is based on a valuation model that uses inputs which are not observable in the market, it follows the same in/i.righttial recognit/i.righton accounting policy as for other financ/i.rightal assets and liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes. All derivat/i.rightves are carried as assets when fair value is posit/i.rightve and as liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes when fair value is negative.

## Hedge accounting

Under certain condit/i.rightons, the Group may designate a recognised asset or liab/i.rightlity, a firm commitment, highly probable forecast transaction or net investment of a foreign operation into a formal hedge accounting relationsh/i.rightp with a derivat/i.rightve that has been entered to manage interest rate and/or foreign exchange risks present in the hedged item. The Group applies the 'Phase 1' hedge accounting requirements of IAS 39 Financ/i.rightal Instruments: Recognit/i.righton and Measurement and the 'Phase 2' amendments to IFRS in respect of interest rate benchmark reform. There are three categories of hedge relationsh/i.rightps:

- · Fair value hedge: to manage the fair value of interest rate and/or foreign currency risks of recognised assets or liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes or firm commitments
- · Cashflow hedge: to manage interest rate or foreign exchange risk of highly probable future cashflows attributable to a recognised asset or liab/i.rightlity, or a forecasted transaction
- · Net investment hedge: to manage the structural foreign exchange risk of an investment in a foreign operation.

The Group formally documents at the incept/i.righton of the transaction the relationsh/i.rightp between hedging instruments and hedged items, as well as its risk management object/i.rightve and strategy for undertaking hedge transactions. This is described in more detail in the categories of hedges below.

The Group assesses, both at hedge incept/i.righton and on a quarterly basis, whether the derivat/i.rightves designated in hedge relationsh/i.rightps are highly effective in offsetting changes in fair values or cashflows of hedged items. Hedges are considered to be highly effective if all the following criter/i.righta are met:

- · At incept/i.righton of the hedge and throughout its life, the hedge is prospectively expected to be highly effective in achiev/i.rightng offsetting changes in fair value or cash flows attributable to the hedged risk
- · Actual results of the hedge are with/i.rightn a range of 80-125%. This is tested using regression analysis
- · The regression co-effic/i.rightent (R squared), which measures the correlation between the variables in the regression, is at least 80%
- · In the case of the hedge of a forecast transaction, the transaction must have a high probabil/i.rightty of occurring and must present an exposure to variat/i.rightons in cashflows that are expected to affect reported profit or loss. The Group assumes that any interest rate benchmarks on which hedged item cashflows are based are not altered by IBOR reform.

The Group discont/i.rightnues hedge accounting in any of the following circumstances:

- · The hedging instrument is not, or has ceased to be, highly effective as a hedge
- · The hedging instrument has expired, is sold, terminated, or exercised
- · The hedged item matures, is sold, or repaid
- · The forecast transaction is no longer deemed highly probable
- · The Group elects to discont/i.rightnue hedge accounting voluntarily

For interest rate benchmarks deemed in scope of IBOR reform, if the actual result of a hedge is outside the 80-125% range, but the hedge passes the prospective assessment, then the Group will not de-designate the hedge relationsh/i.rightp.

Under the Phase 2 Interest Rate Benchmark Reform amendments to IFRS 9 and IAS 39, the Group may change hedge designat/i.rightons and corresponding documentation without the hedge being discont/i.rightnued where there is a change in interest rate benchmark of the hedged item, hedging instrument or designated hedged risk. Permitted changes include the right to:

- · Redefine the hedged risk to reference an alternative risk-free rate
- · Change the method for assessing hedge effectiveness due to modif/i.rightcations required by IBOR reform

A hedge designat/i.righton may be modif/i.righted more than once, each time a relationsh/i.rightp is affected as a direct result of IBOR reform.

## Fair value hedge

Changes in the fair value of derivat/i.rightves that are designated and qualify as fair value hedging instruments are recorded in net trading income, together with any changes in the fair value of the hedged asset or liab/i.rightlity that are attributable to the hedged risk. If the hedge no longer meets the criter/i.righta for hedge accounting, the adjustment to the carrying amount of a hedged item for which the effective interest method is used is amortised to the income statement over the remain/i.rightng term to maturity of the hedged item. If the hedged item is sold or repaid, the unamortised fair value adjustment is recognised immed/i.rightately in the income statement. For financ/i.rightal assets classif/i.righted as fair value through other comprehensive income, the hedge accounting adjustment attributable to the hedged risk is included in net trading income to match the hedging derivat/i.rightve.

## Cashflow hedge

The effective portion of changes in the fair value of derivat/i.rightves that are designated and qualify as cashflow hedging instruments are in/i.righttially recognised in other comprehensive income, accumulating in the cashflow hedge reserve with/i.rightn equity. These amounts are subsequently recycled to the income statement in the periods when the hedged item affects profit or loss. If a cash flow hedge is discont/i.rightnued, the amount accumulated in the cashflow hedge reserve is released to the income statement as and when the hedged item affects the income statement.

Hedges of net investments are accounted for in a sim/i.rightlar manner to cashflow hedges, with gains and losses aris/i.rightng on the effective portion of the hedges recorded in the line 'Exchange differences on translation of foreign operations' in other comprehensive income, accumulating in the translation reserve with/i.rightn equity. ## Cashflow hedges

The Group has exposure to market movements in future interest cashflows on portfolios of customer accounts, debt securit/i.rightes and loans and advances to customers. The amounts and tim/i.rightng of future cashflows, representing both princ/i.rightpal and interest flows, are projected on the basis of contractual terms and other relevant factors, includ/i.rightng estimates of prepayments and defaults.

The hedging strategy of the Group involves using interest rate swaps to manage the variab/i.rightlity in future cashflows on assets and liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes that have floating rates of interest by exchanging the floating rates for fixed rates. It also uses foreign exchange contracts and currency swaps to manage the variab/i.rightlity in future exchange rates on its assets and liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes and costs in foreign currencies. This is done on both a micro basis, whereby a single interest rate or cross-currency swap is designated in a separate relationsh/i.rightp with a single hedged item (such as a floating rate loan to a customer), and on a portfolio basis, whereby each hedging instrument is designated against a group of hedged items that share the same risk (such as a group of customer accounts).

The hedged risk is determined as the variab/i.rightlity of future cashflows aris/i.rightng from changes in the designated benchmark interest rate.

## Interest rate benchmark reform

The Group applies the Phase 1 Interest Rate Benchmark Reform Amendments to IFRS 9, IAS 39 and IFRS 7 which allow the Group to assume that the interest rate benchmark on which cashflows for the hedged item and/or hedging instrument are based is are altered as a result of IBOR reform for the following activ/i.rightties:

- · Prospective hedge assessment
- · Determin/i.rightng whether a cash flow or forecast transaction for a cashflow hedge is highly probable. However, the Group otherwise assesses whether the cashflows are considered highly probable
- · Determin/i.rightng when cumulative balances in the cashflow hedge reserve from de-designated hedges should be recycled to the income statement

The Group will not de-designate a hedge relationsh/i.rightp of a benchmark in scope of IBOR reform if the retrospective hedge result is outside the required 80-125% range but, the hedge passes the prospective assessment. Any hedge ineffect/i.rightveness continues to be recorded in net trading income.

## Accounting policy

The Group assesses whether a contract is a lease in scope of this policy by determin/i.rightng whether the contract gives it the right to use a specif/i.righted underlying physical asset for a lease term greater than 12 months, unless the underlying asset is of low value.

The liab/i.rightlity is recognised in 'Other liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes'. A corresponding right-of-use asset equal to the liab/i.rightlity, adjusted for any lease payments made at or before the commencement date, is recognised in 'Property, plant and equipment'. The lease term includes any extension options contained in the contract that the Group is reasonably certain it will exercise.

The Group subsequently depreciates the right-of-use asset using the straight-line method over the lease term and measures the lease liab/i.rightlity using the effective interest method. Depreciat/i.righton on the asset is recognised in 'Depreciat/i.righton and amortisat/i.righton', and interest on the lease liab/i.rightlity is recognised in 'Interest expense'.

If a leased premise, or a physically dist/i.rightnct portion of a premise such as an ind/i.rightvidual floor, is deemed by management to be surplus to the Group's needs and action has been taken to abandon the space before the lease expires, this is considered an ind/i.rightcator of impa/i.rightrment. ## 30. Retirement benefit obligat/i.rightons

## Accounting policy

The Group operates pension and other post-retirement benefit plans around the world, which can be categorised into defined contribut/i.righton plans and defined benefit plans. For defined contribut/i.righton plans, the Group pays contribut/i.rightons to publicly or privately admin/i.rightstered pension plans on a statutory or contractual basis, and such amounts are charged to operating expenses. The Group has no further payment obligat/i.rightons once the contribut/i.rightons have been paid.

For funded defined benefit plans, the liab/i.rightlity recognised in the balance sheet is the present value of the defined benefit obligat/i.righton at the balance sheet date less the fair value of plan assets. For unfunded defined benefit plans the liab/i.rightlity recognised at the balance sheet date is the present value of the defined benefit obligat/i.righton.

The defined benefit obligat/i.righton is calculated annually by independent actuaries using the projected unit method.

Actuarial gains and losses that arise are recognised in shareholders' equity and presented in the statement of other comprehensive income in the period they arise. The Group determines the net interest expense on the net defined benefit liab/i.rightlity for the year by applying the discount rate used to measure the defined benefit obligat/i.righton at the beginn/i.rightng of the annual period to the net defined benefit liab/i.rightlity, taking into account any changes in the net defined benefit liab/i.rightlity during the year as a result of contribut/i.rightons and benefit payments. Net interest expense, the cost of the accrual of new benefits, benefit enhancements (or reductions) and admin/i.rightstration expenses met directly from plan assets are recognised in the income statement in the period in which they were incurred.

## Sign/i.rightficant accounting estimates and judgements

There are many factors that affect the measurement of the retirement benefit obligat/i.rightons. This measurement requires the use of estimates, such as discount rates, inflat/i.righton, pension increases, salary increases, and life expectancies which are inherently uncertain. Discount rates are determined by reference to market yields at the end of the reporting period on high-quality corporate bonds (or, in countries where there is no deep market in such bonds, government bonds) of a currency and term consistent with the currency and term of the post-employment benefit obligat/i.rightons. This is the approach adopted across our geographies. Where there are inflat/i.righton-linked bonds available (e.g. United Kingdom and the eurozone), the Group derives inflat/i.righton based on the market on those bonds, with the market yield adjusted in respect of the United Kingdom to take account of the fact that liab/i.rightlit/i.rightes are linked to Consumer Price Index inflat/i.righton, whereas the reference bonds are linked to Retail Price Index inflat/i.righton. Where no inflat/i.righton-linked bonds exist, we determine inflat/i.righton assumptions based on a combinat/i.righton of long-term forecasts and short-term inflat/i.righton data. Salary growth assumptions reflect the Group's long-term expectations, taking into account future business plans and macroeconomic data (primar/i.rightly expected future long-term inflat/i.righton). Demographic assumptions, includ/i.rightng mortality and turnover rates, are typically set based on the assumptions used in the most recent actuarial funding valuation, and will generally use industry standard tables, adjusted where appropriate to reflect recent histor/i.rightc experience and/or future expectations. ## Accounting policy

The Group operates equity-settled and cash-settled share-based compensation plans. The fair value of the employee services (measured by the fair value of the awards granted) received in exchange for the grant of the shares and awards is recognised as an expense. For deferred share awards granted as part of an annual performance award, the expense is recognised over the period from the start of the performance period to the vesting date. For example, the expense for three-year awards granted in 2022 in respect of 2021 performance, which vest in 2023-2025, is recognised as an expense over the period from 1 January 2021 to the vesting dates in 2023-2025. For all other awards, the expense is recognised over the period from the date of grant to the vesting date.

For equity-settled awards, the total amount to be expensed over the vesting period is determined by reference to the fair value of the shares and awards at the date of grant, which excludes the impact of any non-market vesting condit/i.rightons (for example, profitab/i.rightlity and growth targets). The fair value of equity instruments granted is based on market prices, if available, at the date of grant. In the absence of market prices, the fair value of the instruments is estimated using an appropriate valuation technique, such as a binom/i.rightal option pric/i.rightng model. Non-market vesting condit/i.rightons are included in assumptions for the number of shares and awards that are expected to vest.

At each balance sheet date, the Group revises its estimates of the number of shares and awards that are expected to vest. It recognises the impact of the revis/i.righton of orig/i.rightnal estimates, if any, in the income statement and a corresponding adjustment to equity over the remain/i.rightng vesting period. Forfeitures prior to vesting attributable to factors other than the failure to satisfy service condit/i.rightons and non-market vesting condit/i.rightons are treated as a cancellation and the remain/i.rightng unamortised charge is debited to the income statement at the time of cancellation. The proceeds received net of any directly attributable transaction costs are credited to share capital (nominal value) and share premium when awards in the form of options are exercised.

Cash-settled awards are revalued at each balance sheet date and a liab/i.rightlity recognised on the balance sheet for all unpaid amounts, with any changes in fair value charged or credited to staff costs in the income statement until the awards are exercised. Where forfeitures occur prior to vesting that are attributable to factors other than a failure to satisfy service condit/i.rightons or market-based performance condit/i.rightons, the cumulative charge incurred up to the date of forfeiture is credited to the income statement. Any revaluation related to cash-settled awards is recorded as an amount due from subsid/i.rightary undertakings.

The 2021 Plan was approved by shareholders in May 2021 and is the Group's main share plan, replacing the 2011 Plan for new awards, June 2021. It may be used to deliver various types of share awards, previously granted under the 2011 Plan:

- · Deferred awards are used to deliver the deferred portion of variable remuneration, in line with both market practice and regulatory requirements. This enables the Group to meet regulatory requirements relating to deferral levels, and is in line with market practice
- · Restricted share awards, made outside of the annual performance process as replacement buy-out awards to new jo/i.rightners who forfeit awards on leaving their previous employers, vest in instalments on the anniversar/i.rightes of the award date specif/i.righted at the time of grant.
